channel.title: Which distro should I DL?
channel.description:
Heyyyyyyyyy,
I wanna put something on my laptop to play around with, and for every day use. I was sick of Linpus (based off Fedora), because it kept fucking up and would take 20mins to load up for some retarded reason, so I put Windows XP in place... now I don't mind WinXP it's just it's boring.
soya, go go go.

item.title: Which distro should I DL?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Ralink is another one that some people think is difficult, when in fact the drivers are always there by default, its just that some distros don’t distribute the firmware. It’s as easy as grabbing the rt61/rt2x00-fw package from your distro’s repos.

Read full topic

item.title: Which distro should I DL?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Starting up …, post:23, topic:297914”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=394287.msg2938179#msg2938179 date=1251684703]

[quote author=Starting up … link=topic=394287.msg2937938#msg2937938 date=1251669420]

PS. IDK about K/Xubuntu, but Ubuntu is fucking retarded for wireless shit. -___-

Generally, if you want wireless, your best chance of getting it to work out of the box is using an ubuntu distro, since that is what they try to do.

Of course you can make it work on any distro, you just might have to do some extra work, depending on the chipset of course.
[/quote]Most Distro’s Wireless works right away for me…

As I said, it depends on the chipset.
[/quote]I forgot to mention that my chipset is some off brand crap.[/quote]

Can you name it? Broadcom for one almost never works out of the box, even though B43 support is much better than the old bcm43xx driver, you still need to download proprietary firmware that the distros can’t distribute. Atheros and Intel chipsets usually work out of the box though.

Read full topic

item.title: Which distro should I DL?
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

Yarly, I haven’t had a wireless problem with *ubuntu since Hoary, which was 5.04 iirc. Except once with server edition, but that was fixed in 20 minutes with ndiswrapper.

Also notable, Windows 7 is the first version of windows that hasn’t required me to install wireless drivers.

Read full topic

item.title: Which distro should I DL?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

how hard is installing a driver, jesus christ

theres plenty of hardware that dosent work out of the box on windows, too, and where finding the driver is a lot harder - yet nobody ever complains about that :S

Read full topic

item.title: Which distro should I DL?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Uriko:

PS. IDK about K/Xubuntu, but Ubuntu is fucking retarded for wireless shit. -___-

Generally, if you want wireless, your best chance of getting it to work out of the box is using an ubuntu distro, since that is what they try to do.

Of course you can make it work on any distro, you just might have to do some extra work, depending on the chipset of course.

Read full topic

item.title: Which distro should I DL?
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:8, topic:297914”]But Arch (or Gentoo) is not a distro for beginners, you have to edit configuration files and be pretty familiar and comfortable with the command line to use it, and then things are going to break and you aren’t going to know how to fix them. Don’t get me wrong, it is a great distro, just not for beginners. Debian is like that as well, just much less likely to break (if you use stable) and you don’t have to edit configuration files for the most part.

For a beginner, Kubuntu (or Xubuntu, you choose) is a great distro, and it doesn’t lose it’s usefulness with experience, it is also good for the expert as you can do all the things with it as you would any other distro.[/quote]Thing is, he never said he was a beginner

Also the beginner’s guide is VERY thorough and contains everything you’d ever need + if you don’t try you’ll never learn

One more thing, setting up debian from scratch was pretty much the same thing as setting up arch.

Read full topic

item.title: Which distro should I DL?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

But Arch (or Gentoo) is not a distro for beginners, you have to edit configuration files and be pretty familiar and comfortable with the command line to use it, and then things are going to break and you aren’t going to know how to fix them. Don’t get me wrong, it is a great distro, just not for beginners. Debian is like that as well, just much less likely to break (if you use stable) and you don’t have to edit configuration files for the most part.

For a beginner, Kubuntu (or Xubuntu, you choose) is a great distro, and it doesn’t lose it’s usefulness with experience, it is also good for the expert as you can do all the things with it as you would any other distro.

Read full topic

item.title: Which distro should I DL?
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:4, topic:297914”]If you have little experience with Linux, I wouldn’t go with Arch or Gentoo. Just install xubuntu cause it’s fast as fuck and you won’t need to spend hours installing it.[/quote]Sry but it takes about 15 minutes max to install arch with graphical support, proprietary driver, a nice wm and pretty much everythin else u need + huge beginner’s tutorial that covers everything.

I got my system up and running in about 25 minutes, and my first non-graphical distro was arch.

Read full topic
